I love Elvis hair. They were going two damn miles an hour.
Three Adam Five -- show us 1019 to the jail with one male prisoner.
I just dealt with the situation.
He grabbed me.     End of story.
If you think I crossed the line, put it in the report.
Not you, Rob. You're a rare unthreatened male cop with a good marriage, and you like to eat where I eat -- so everything's code four.
Thanks. But  she'll invite friends, try and fix me up. She's always trying to fix me up so she doesn't have to worry about you and me.

You don't need to fix me, Robby, or fix me up. I don't want some guy to heart and soul me and then walk away 'cause he can't stand the cop thing -- or worse: he wants cop stories every night 'cause it turns him on, and he has no idea who I am inside my head.
Hi, Mrs. Vander. You're looking good.
So, I guess I'll see you.
Kathy and the boy? Bet he's big now.

Place is coming along nice. The octagon window. Dad's signature.

So you really weren't going to tell me? Nobody was going to tell me? Mom and Dad renewing their vows, the church, the party. Mrs.
It's my family. Jesus, Lar. It's over ten years, and he won't let go of it.
Hey, Champ, my God, look how big.
Ow! You hurt my hand with that grip. Whew.
Take it easy.    You too, Champ.
Oh, no. You're not breaking my fingers again.
He had me.    I was dead.
I like how you're always asking the big questions, Ray.

For someone you don't even know?

Get in the car, will you?
Are you one of those people who drive ten miles an hour in the rain? I hate that.
Oh yeah?   What am I doing there?
I'm not pissed off at you.

Every time I close my eyes, I see that goddamn gun pointing at me and I don't know why I'm telling you unless it's because you were there and because I had three drinks, but I'm not ready to go inside and close my eyes and I don't want to go to your place and I don't want to keep driving around, so what the hell do we do?
What I want  is to know how you happened to  be walking by that parking lot  at that minute. What if you hadn' t been there?
If you want -- you can come in for a minute.
You're not supposed to look around. I didn't have time to straighten up.
I'm not mad. You'll know when I'm mad. I don't usually let somebody in here, but here you are. That's all. Let's talk about something stupid.

Oh.    You're here as a medic.

Looks the same. Still smells like cigarettes. I thought he quit.

Did Larry tell you I came by where he's working? Is that why you called me?

How come you're renewing your vows?
Sorry.  I wish I did, too.
Does he? Remember any good about me?
Oh? How come you forgot what he did?

Will you hang up please, and I'll call your machine.

Or like me, right? What about you? How come you can see?
Let's go talk in the yard.

I'm sorry I hit you so hard.

Because the job's all I got.

Yesterday. Okay. Yesterday we rolled on a 415. Juliette and Sanchez had these four guys against a wall, but they were H.D.B. and definitely unco-op. It got pretty jumpy, but we got them in the car with a couple of bruises and Robby got a sprained wrist, so I did the rest of the shift with a rookie who lost it over a D.B. in Sunset Park, old woman who'd been dead maybe six, seven days, and I usually do all right but the smell got to me, and I can still smell her. Then we arrested a prostitute working out of her home, and I carried her little girl out to the social worker, and the kid was holding on real tight and making my shoulder wet and I wanted to punch her rock-head mother, and then shift ended and I had a nice visit with my brother Larry.
What if a park ranger comes?!
We should be thinking about lunch.
Some of us have to work.
I have to check these jacket pockets. What's your name --
I need to unsnap this, Allison.
Lift your arms higher. Got a good basketball team at St. Mark's.
Well, it's a mix, Robby. Life is shit, but I'm dating this great dead guy.

Then put that bat away.   Put it in your trunk. Now.
Pickup.        Ow.   Ow! That's really good.

How come it's not working for you?

dressed differently, re-wrapping the gift and then --

sitting still in a chair, holding the gift on her lap, looking at the clock, nervous, scared, sad.

Do you want me here? Do you love me, Dad? I want to know.

Let's roll to this -- fight in progress.
As I remove your cuffs, I want you to put your hands here. Spread your legs. More.

Pogo, stop the shit. What is it?
Got some action, huh?    Well, that's promising.
What's going on, Pogo?    You're not happy or anything?
This time we got his ass.
Are you going to tell me why we're sitting outside this building again?
Fine -- what am I supposed to do?
Right now your mind's making pictures of me robbing your groceires, but, y'know, nine times out of ten, people do the right thing.
Hey! You want to turn that volume down? What's your point?
What's the point of blasting your music through the whole zip code?
Why?   What're you gonna do?   Kill me?
I was just walking by.      I live near here.
I got you nectarines because the peaches are hard as rocks.
He had the ball. He was going for a touchdown.

He was going to shoot you.
No. I didn't have time to think about it.

Where do you want to be ten years from now?

No. Really. I just remembered it -- God is my witness.
I don't know.    This is pretty good.
The only time I worry is when people tell me not to worry.
I'm on Lundy Street, just off Pico.

I guess we were supposed to meet.
Now that I'm in here, you seem mad about it.
Some people say we each give off a particular odor -- that can only be detected by one other person's brain.
I'm more in the destiny school, we-met-in-another-life school. Do you believe that? Do you think when we die -- we come back in another form?
See?   Now you're thinking about me.
Can I come back some time?
Hey!   Hey!    Wake up!    Wake up!
Okay, an 'appointment.'     I keep my appointments.
I get up early. I walked there.
Come back? What makes you think I'd come back here?

My name is Catch Lambert. I don't work. I don't commit any crimes.
And I need to start from here.
This is what you told me about --
Your interrogation.      Do I need a lawyer?
What is it you're looking for?
This is it. I sleep here. I walk around town. That's all of it.
Yeah. Except for you -- the way I feel about you.
No. Did you ever wonder what 'scratch' meant, when people say, 'we'll start from scratch'? This is scratch. We can start from here.
You know the cop -- the woman cop?
She has a lot of questions.    She wants to know everything.
We could start from today.    What's so wrong with that?
She's sort of pissed-off at me.
I'm sorry I yelled at you.
Will you get off this street?
If you take a right and stop -- we can walk from here. I'd rather walk.
Forget about him. Somebody I used to know. I don't want to know him anymore. That's all. Forget about it. Walk with me.
I like it here. It's fine.
She feels bad 'cause you yelled at her.
She just needs you to smile at her.
Why not smile at her?   What's it cost?
You're so busy being pissed off, and time is going by.
Maybe she'll think about it now.
Don't tell me what my problem is!
Maybe it's not my problem. Maybe it's your problem. Maybe you're going around blind.
Blind to what's going on around you. Blind to what people need.
I'll call you later -- about the hiking.
Hey. Hey!   Can you wait up a minute?!
The city is flat. Okay? Can we stop here? Can we examine the view? Have a Milky Way? I've burned every calorie I ever had.
I'm not one of those competitive guys, you know!
No thanks. I can't eat and have a heart attack at the same time.
As soon as you get happy, you get sad.
Fine? This isn't fine. I know fine. This is something else.
All my days are the same.
I'm sorry. That would make anybody sad.
No.   No, you can always tell me.
Take your badge off for once.
They tell me I was in an accident.
We don't need to go there.
I want my old job back.
No, but I'm up to speed.
No thanks, Ray. Everything's code four. Go away.
One more word, and your life will change forever.
I didn't know it bothered anybody until you mentioned it. You arresting me?
You going to tell me where we're going?
This is wrong! It's wrong!   Why are you doing this?!
I don't need your help! I don't need this. We don't need this --

I'm not dying! I'm not pretending! I don't remember! I don't remember any of it. So leave me alone! What good does it do? It's gone! And I'm all right this way! Why do you have to change it? I'm all right.
Damn you, Shar. Damn you -- why won't you stop?!
I have a life! We could have a life. We could get up and go to work and come home to each other and never, never talk about before. We don't need to do that!
Nothing happened! If we say it, then that's the truth, that can be the truth. Say it. Nothing happened. Say it, Shar.
Say it!    I'm asking you to say it.
Why are   you pushing so hard? Why does it   have to be your way? Why does it   have to be your truth?
You like to push people, don't you? You just have to push and shove and make it right for you --
You already said it.   You said it all.
I woke up, and you were gone.
at the grave, struggling through this.

That ain't the touch.   That ain't the touch I want.

I don't want you around here.

Nice, huh? Beautiful. The cops'll love this, right?

That's not your business! Nobody called you, right? She didn't ask for you to come here. This is my family. You don't get it, 'cause you've got no family. Nobody. So you try to run everybody else's life. Jesus Christ -- get your own life. That's the goddam problem. Get your own goddamn life.
That's what I said, right?    No life.

Stunned by the sight of her -- and he doesn't know why.
He is shaken, too.    Sanchez is taking notes as Ray checks his I.D.
As he puts the mouthpiece on the horn, nervous, but excited, too, speaking to the Piano Player.
He watches Tommy at play with the figures, but it's almost too much for him. He touches the boy and rises, smiles and nods at Candace and begins to walk off.

But he is walking on, some of the emotion seeping through, not darkness, some old joy welling up. We see, in b.g., Tommy starts to run after him to say thanks. We now have a convergence of Tommy, Sharon and Catch, who is moving steadily toward the street, crossing a bike path now. A BIKER is coming on. All in one moment Catch hears the WHIZZ of the BIKE, Tommy calling out "Thank you," and Candace shouting "Be careful!" And Catch goes cold inside and turns quickly and rushes onto the bike path, taking the collision with the bike so Tommy is sure to be safe. Catch and the biker fall hard. Sharon stops -- holding her breath. Tommy watches, wide-eyed, and Candace comes running.
The police car is now converging with other squads just half a block away. Catch throws the ball back to the boys and runs toward the police incident. The boys watch him go, wondering.
This sliver of memory jolts HIM -- and then another one comes.
by the angry DRIVER shouting at him.

Catch stands there shaken and shut down.

That's his way. That's his way through all this. He made a wall -- around that whole day, that night -- other things, too. He keeps them behind the wall -- his little boy, my daughter. He can't help it. The cemetery?! Do you know how hard it is for me to go to the cemetery? Can you imagine?
That's where it stares you in the face -- the loss. And it's too much sometimes.

in the mirror and see how shaken she still is.

coming closer and the scream of brakes from his memory, and all of this is exploded --

We see Larry, across the room, notice this hug. He keeps his expression intact for the group he's in, but we see a flare of anger in his eyes.

as Sharon walks to him, so glad he's there, needing him -- but still not sure of what he's feeling about her, until she gets close and sees his eyes and the way he opens his arms -- and they embrace, and she holds on tight, eyes closed.
